caption: The entrance according to google instructions is locked, please go in the opposite direction. You will see a large yard and ring the bell for them to open the door. You will need to leave your personal documents at the security room, they will give you a visiting card (you will get your documents back after the tour ends). The museum is located on the grounds of a still-operating school, so ask the tour guide about the permitted locations. Tickets are only 5€ and hardly many people know about this museum. I highly recommend everyone to visit.

The entrance is located across the street from the southern end of Place Alphonse Laveran, there you have to buzz the tiny gate to get in and you have to give the guard your ID. Makes sense since it is a working military institution.  Very interesting subject matter, lots of cool interesting displays (albeit a bit gory). There's even the folio for the nobel prize of Alphonse Laveran. There is also the beautiful church and dome. Very few people there which is a nice change for a Parisian museum. 5€ for entry, 2€50 for reduced ticket (incl. students).

An intimate museum with few visitors and much of charm (even if its subject is rather disturbing). Entering is a bit 'nonstandard' since at the gates you need to call on the intercom, and then leave your ID at the reception to get a visitor card (the building is a military facility). I strongly recommend a visit, e.g. after seeing the Pantheon (it's not far from there). The only minus is that descriptions are in French only, it's worth to translate them with e.g. Google Lens since they are quite interesting.

The Museum of the Armed Forces Health Service is a fascinating and unique institution that showcases the history and evolution of medical services in the military. In several countries around the world, this museum is a must-visit for history buffs, medical professionals, and anyone interested in the intersection of medicine and warfare.  The exhibits in the museum cover a wide range of topics, from the development of battlefield medicine and surgery to the advances in mental health care for soldiers. Visitors can learn about the different medical technologies and tools used in the past, as well as the innovative approaches used in present-day military medicine.  One of the most interesting aspects of the museum is its collection of artifacts, which include uniforms, equipment, medical supplies, and even prosthetics used by injured soldiers. These artifacts provide a unique insight into the experiences of military medical personnel and their patients.  Besides its permanent exhibits, the museum also hosts temporary exhibitions and events that showcase current research and developments in military medicine. These events provide an opportunity for visitors to learn about the latest innovations in the field and to engage with experts in the industry.  Overall, the Museum of the Armed Forces Health Service is a valuable resource for anyone interested in the history and evolution of military medicine. Its exhibits and events provide a unique insight into the important role that medical services play in supporting the men and women who serve in the armed forces.

Beautiful museum offering a unique insight into the health conditions of the French Armed Forces throughout the past centuries. Interesting stories, fascinating statues and artifacts, kind staff. The building itself is stunning inside and out. Visiting on a Saturday morning, we had the museum for ourselves.

This is quirky museum but one we enjoyed.  First, you have to find the place.  Go to the far end of the fence in front of the Val-de-Grace church and press button to get buzzed through the gate.  Then check in at the window where they held our passports during the visit.  I think it is somehow a military prooperty, thus the passport thing.  Fee was 5 Euro.  If you are interested in military history and/or the medical field, you will find it interesting.  Otherwise, maybe not.  But one of the best things was the access to the interior of the Val-de-Grace Church, not accessible otherwise.  We were basically the only ones in the museum and we had the church all to ourselves, which was magical.  It has a stunning interior.  So this alone made it worth the trouble of finding the place.  There were also clean bathrooms available, which is always appreciated in Paris.  Finally, don’t believe the Google Maps directions, which tried to take us through a chained gate from Blvd Port-Royal.  Enter from Rue Saint Jacques.  ENJOY!!!
Everything is in French, but the church alone is worth a visit.

This is perhaps the strangest museum in Paris, not because of its content, just the whole thing. I have lived exactly facing the museum for a year, but aside from a sign it is impossible to realize there is museum there at all. Incredibly weird!!!!  It is as if the closed gates tell you, stay away and keep off and don't come back. The whole place says you are unwelcomed. Weird..  There is a very, very, very SMALL SIGN, written in French that says if you want to enter the museum you have to ring a bell. Then someone buzzes you in. Then you have to go to a guard, give an ID card, they will give you badge to wear, then you go and pay 5 Euro to get in... I must have walked by the place a million times wondering whether I should buzz  or not.. I don't know WHY they just don't keep the door open...Weird, Weird, Weird....  As for the museum itself..the entry fee is cheap, there is never a line and the museum is often pretty empty. I was the only person there. The collection itself is, as advertised, mostly medical history. So, if that interests you, it's a nice visit. See my photos. A lot of historical medical pieces. You can probably see the whole thing in 60 minutes. Would I recommend a visit? Only if you are in the area and interested in medical history. There is so much more to do in Paris though. Also remember the hours are very limited. It is closed on Mondays and Fridays..and on other days only from 12:00 to 6:00 pm. Maybe if they made the museum more welcoming more people would visit. People were nice though..A C-level place to visit.
If as a tourist you carry your passport with you while sightseeing, you will be allowed in. If not -like me- you won't, with no conciliatory proposal.
Where those soldiers of the French military who lost their face in the fierce battles in World War One named les Gueules cassées where getting the best attentions in the new field of plastic surgery
An interesting display of the history of army medicine. Worth a visit if you’re in the area.
Very difficult to find (took many wrong turns, directions wrong on google) and then they did not accept card just cash.
It's a wonderful and gorgeous place to be
Worth stopping by if you like history.
Very interesting and informative
A true hidden gem of Paris.
Beautiful !
Original but sensible idea. The permanent exhibition on health services is very good, very educational. We liked the chapel less. The (military) personnel were very warm.

The museum's biggest problem is finding the right door and getting inside. You usually expect an entrance that will be clearly marked, open during opening hours... Well, there is a big arrow here, but the instructions at the door are not very clear. But you have to ring the bell (in addition, there are probably more buttons...), they will open the door for you with a buzzer. Then you go through and come to the gatehouse, leave your document there, they will give you a visitor's card. Then enter the door opposite and there is an entrance fee, a cloakroom and so on. It is one of the cheaper museums in Paris. Not very modern, the screens didn't work. But again, it's good to realize how terrible war is and especially that there are people who try to save people in war, even within the army.

A small museum about military medicine. As it is an active military facility, you will need a passport or other form of identification to visit. To the right of the front fence facing Place Alphonse Laveran on Rue Saint-Jacques, there is a small locked gate that allows you to enter by ringing the doorbell. A banner reading "Musée du Service de santé des armées" hangs from the front fence. From there, walk through the forecourt, leave your passport at the gate, receive an admission pass in exchange, and proceed to the museum entrance. Entrance fee to the museum is 5 euros (credit card accepted). A museum that summarizes the history of medical care in the military, displaying old medical equipment and paintings and photographs of emergency medical care on the battlefield. I'm here. The museum building itself is a renovated old military hospital, so you can feel the weight of history. From inside the museum, you can access the chapel of the adjacent Val de Glace church through a passageway.

The entrance is not the easiest to find! The price is low for the size of the museum. The chapel is magnificent. The temporary exhibition smaller and less developed than I expected. The permanent collections are interesting. It was too hot upstairs though. No locker room. And don't forget your identity card at the entrance (which you must leave for a military pass).

The museum is located in the old buildings of the 17th century abbey. Entering the courtyard, we see the church whose dome is one of the oldest in the capital.  We can admire, - the 17th century cloister, the old abbey, apothecary jars, old stretchers, a tapestry representing "The Imaginary Sick", etc......  The library, open to the public, was inaugurated by François Mitterrand on May 22, 1990. She owns more than 60,000 books.  Finally, you can see the temporary exhibition of Raymond Depardon (until January 30), military photographer in 1962-1963.

Uncrowded museum which is rare in Paris No information on arrival The major importance of war medicine deserves to be highlighted more, lack of brightness in terms of information and exhibitions, screens which no longer work Exceptional church not to be missed

The Army Health Service Museum was founded in 1916 in Val-de-Grâce. It is located at 1, place Alphonse-Laveran in the 5th arrondissement of Paris. However, the archives attest to the existence of a natural history cabinet, bringing together various objects, made available to students. It would be necessary to wait for the circular of May 5, 1916 for such a body to be set up. The museum has been open to the public since 1986.  It is recognition of the work done by men to save others by following its evolution over time since 1796.  To be discovered during the night of the Museums with an extension towards the Val de Grace church.
A moving and captivating place retracing the dedication of health teams and the suffering linked to war for soldiers
A magnificent place which is not very open to the public because it has a military vocation, but try it during Heritage Days. To check with the Ministry of the Armed Forces as a precaution
Great visit, a little-known museum but lots of interesting things to discover
Magnificent museum..... Opening hours 12 noon to 6 p.m., entry 5 euros..except Monday and Friday The entire history of French army medicine. Magnificent setting... Currently, exhibition of Depardon..

Great museum, very little known. There are beautiful objects (like uniforms) and the subject of the evolution of army health services is very interesting. In addition, the setting is magnificent, particularly the Val de Grace church. Small downside, if the old-fashioned side of the scenographies and windows is rather nice, the lack of budget for the management of the museum is a shame (lots of burnt out bulbs, all the screens no longer work).
Discreet museum which reveals an impressive church and the history of "military" medicine which deserves to be discovered.

Very beautiful monument, discovered by chance at the bend of a street. It seems that it is possible to make visits: Museum of the Army Health Service (open Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday, Saturday and Sunday from 12 p.m. to 6 p.m., full price €5)
Visit on the occasion of heritage days - very beautiful building with a museum section of the army doctor services. To have!
Are you a medic or even one in the military and interested in history? Then you've come to the right place, one of the most impressive museums I've ever visited
Very beautiful museum unfortunately too unknown to the general public. Magnificent exhibitions in a sumptuous and very well presented building. I recommend!!!

The SSA Museum has reopened its doors for JEP 2023: it is now open from 11 a.m. to 5:30 p.m. Come and admire the collections of war medicine over the centuries, and the remarkable architectural heritage of Val-de-Grâce.
Very nice and little-known museum in the heart of Paris
A great discovery “Private” visit because I was alone during my entire visit Little known but very interesting museum Magnificent setting
A museum to discover and a magnificent church!
